thread.title: Credit card interest rates: the truth
thread.title_full: Credit card interest rates: the truth

author: John Rolfe Cost of Living Editor
title: Credit card interest rates: the truth
text:
WESTPAC has been sprung twisting statistics to hide the great credit-card gouge.
In a submission to a Senate inquiry examining card interest rates, Westpac says its “current net margin for credit cards is in line with 2010”.
But the Reserve Bank of Australia’s submission reveals there was a significant expansion in card issuer margins in the period just prior to that Westpac selectively highlighted.
Figures provided to News Corp Australia by the RBA show that between March 2008 and March 2009, the gap between the average credit card interest rate banks charged and their costs jumped from 6.3 percentage points to 9.1 percentage points.
In its submission, the RBA said “spreads rose significantly in the global financial crisis, when funding rates fell significantly but credit card rates fell by much less, and have remained at that level or drifted modestly higher since.”
While the RBA noted most customers do not usually pay interest on their credit cards because they pay off the balance each month, it found that for the 30 to 40 per cent who do pay interest, banks were now charging 14.75 percentage points above their funding costs. Credit gouge .. a graphic from the Reserve Bank’s submission to the Senate credit card inquiry. Source: Supplied
That is up from borrowers paying interest had been only about 10.8 percentage points in 2008.
Westpac makes no mention of this increase since then in its submission.
And it chose not to respond to requests for comment yesterday.
The RBA said those who don’t pay off their balances each month are known as “revolvers”.
This group has more than its fair share of low-income households, the RBA submission shows.
Revolvers are carrying with about two-thirds of Australia’s $51 billion worth of credit card debt.
The Customer Owned Banking Association, which represents credit unions and building societies, said in its submission that it was possible to get a credit card with an interest rate as low as 7.99 per cent. That Visa card is offered by Sydney-based Quay Credit Union. It comes with a six-month zero per cent balance transfer. Both the purchase rate and cash advance rates are 7.99 per cent.
“There is no need for customers to be paying exorbitant interest rates,” COBA said.
NAB submission said its cards offered “fair value”.
CBA is expected to file a submission this week, as is ANZ.
The senate inquiry is due to have its first hearing in Sydney next week.
The inquiry was set up because of concerns that credit card rates have not responded to repeated cuts to the RBA cash rate, which has been falling since 2011.
